title: PART A: THESIS/CLAIM
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning.

The response responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning the extent to which rights-based discourses succeeded in bringing about social change during the late twentieth century.

title: PART B: CONTEXTUALIZATION
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the prompt.
The response describes a broader historical context relevant to rights-based discourses and social change during the late twentieth century.

title: PART C1: EVIDENCE - PROVIDES EVIDENCE
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn one point, the response must identify at least two specific pieces of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not provide at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.
The response provides at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

title: PART C2: EVIDENCE - USES EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT AN ARGUMENT
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must use at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions:
The response does not support an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.

Examples of evidence used to support an argument:

· “One example of the limits of social change in this period was the resistance to environmental movements such as Greenpeace by powerful business and corporate interests. Some national governments also resisted the environmental movement because they wanted to protect their economic or political interests, as seen in Japan’s opposition to early attempts to ban whaling.”

· “The establishment of the U.N. Universal Declaration of Human Rights brought discussion of the rights of refugees into the open on a global scale and compelled or at least motivated governments to enact legislation to safeguard these rights.”

The response supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.

Examples of evidence used to support an argument:

· “One example of the limits of social change in this period was the resistance to environmental movements such as Greenpeace by powerful business and corporate interests. Some national governments also resisted the environmental movement because they wanted to protect their economic or political interests, as seen in Japan’s opposition to early attempts to ban whaling.”

· “The establishment of the U.N. Universal Declaration of Human Rights brought discussion of the rights of refugees into the open on a global scale and compelled or at least motivated governments to enact legislation to safeguard these rights.”

title: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING -  USES HISTORICAL REASONING
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn the point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument, although the reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.
descriptions:
The response does not use historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, continuity and change ) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt.

· Explaining how the end of the Second World War and the process of decolonization that followed allowed many countries the opportunity to contemplate and implement far reaching social changes, such as access to education for girls in Kenya.

· Explaining how dissident movements in the former Communist bloc, such as the Solidarity Movement in Poland, succeeded in creating a domestic opposition to pro-Soviet governments that undercut the legitimacy of those regimes in terms of their claims to popular representation.

· Comparing how different or similar factors led to social change as a result of rights-based discourses in multiple global regions, for example comparing how the United States Civil Rights movement and Nelson Mandela’s anti-Apartheid movement in South Africa succeeded in delegitimizing racial segregation in those two countries.
Uses historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, continuity and change ) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt.

title: PART D2:  ANALYSIS AND REASONING - COMPLEXITY
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

· Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

· Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.
descriptions: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt.
Demonstrates a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.
